Title: Catalyzing Public Engagement With Climate Change Through Informal Science Learning Centers
Key_Findings: (1) Training presenters increase effectiveness of communication

Title: Using a News Article to Convey Climate Science Consensus Information
Key_Findings: (1) Scientific consensus statement increase perception of scientific consensus,but does not affect other Climate Change attitudes

Title: Aesthetics and Astronomy: Studying the Public’s Perception and Understanding of Imagery From Space
Key_Findings: (1) non-experts are more likely to focus on aesthetic or emotional values of images

Title: After the Flood: Anger,Attribution,and the Seeking of Information
Key_Findings: (1) Anger is associated with information seeking behaviour and processing,as well as greater risk judgment,a greater sense of personal efficacy,lower trust

Title: One or Many? The Influence of Episodic and Thematic Climate Change Frames on Policy Preferences and Individual Behavior Change
Key_Findings:
(1) exposure to thematic frames associated with more support for policies than exposure to episodic frame
(2) no framing effect on disposition for individual behavior change

Title: The Effects of Uncertainty Frames in Three Science Communication Topics
Key_Findings: (1) Portraying scientific findings in uncertainty frames does not have significant effects

Title: Should Scientists Talk About GMOs Nicely? Exploring the Effects of Communication Styles,Source Expertise,and Preexisting Attitude
Key_Findings: (1) Writer likability and perceived expertise was significant (?)

Title: Testing Links Among Uncertainty,Affect,and Attitude Toward a Health Behavior
Output: Information seeking,Information processing,Perceived risk,Intention to act
Key_Findings: (1) worry and anger influence uncertainty judgments and attitudes toward fish avoidance and information insufficiency

Title: Viruses Going Viral: Impact of Fear-Arousing Sensationalist Social Media Messages on User Engagement
Key_Findings: (1) fear arousal increase user engagement

Title: What,Me Worry? The Role of Affect in Information Seeking and Avoidance
Key_Findings: (1) negative affect drives information seeking

Title: Laughing With Science: The Influence of Audience Approval on Engagement
Key_Findings: (1) Affective response is positively linked to engagement

Title: From White Lab Coats and Crazy Hair to Actual Scientists: Exploring the Impact of Researcher Interaction and Performing Arts on Students’ Perceptions and Motivation for Science
Stimulus: In-person  stand up and improv theater
Key_Findings:
(1) Drama based technieques increase interest in scientific careers
(2) interaction with scientists reduce stereotyped perception

Title: Countering the “Harmless E-Cigarette” Myth: The Interplay of Message Format,Message Sidedness,and Prior Experience With E-Cigarette Use in Misinformation Correction
Key_Findings: (1) stories more emotionally involving than nonstories but does not reduce counterarguing when used as correctives

Title: How Effective Are Concrete and Abstract Climate Change Images? The Moderating Role of Construal Level in Climate Change Visual Communication
Stimulus: Images of different General text/color/illustrative scales
Key_Findings: (1) concrete images does not lead to  increased level of concern

Title: Tacit Understandings of Health Literacy: Interview and Survey Research With Health Journalists
Key_Findings: None

Title: To Eat or Not to Eat: Framing of GMOs in American Media and Its Effects on Attitudes and Behaviors
Method: Questionnaire,observed behavior in choice of apple
Key_Findings:
(1) Framng affect attitudes and can change them. 
(2) affect behavioral intentions but not actual behavior

Title: The Effects of the “War on Science” Frame on Scientists’ Credibility
Framing: war on science/challenge for science/neglect of science
Key_Findings: (1) War on science frame makes conservatives report lower agreement with scientist credibility index

Title: Debunking Misinformation About Genetically Modified Food Safety on Social Media: Can Heuristic Cues Mitigate Biased Assimilation?
Key_Findings: (1) Corrective information can counteract influence of misinformation

Title: Mother Nature’s Fury: Antagonist Metaphors for Natural Disasters Increase Forecasts of Their Severity and Encourage Evacuation
Key_Findings:
(1) antagonist framed increase perception of severity
(2) Metaphors are effective for risk communication

Title: “Social Change” and “Status Quo” Framing Effects on Risk Perception: An Exploratory Experiment
Key_Findings: (1) social change framing increase rissk awareness

Title: Information Insufficiency and Information Seeking: An Experiment
Key_Findings: (1) high suffiency threshold result in greater information seeking intention

Title: The Impact of Message Source on the Effectiveness of Communications About Climate Change
Key_Findings: (1) Messages attributed to military leaders or republican party leaders can enhance impact of appeal.

Title: Early Exposures to Ecogenomics: Effects of Priming and Web Site Interactivity Among Adolescents
Method: Attitude questionnaire,observed time invested in information-processing,cognitive load questionnaire
Key_Findings: (1) Priming does not affect attitude development.

Title: Increasing Information Seeking About Antibiotic Risks: Testing a Clinical Intervention Message Using the Risk Information Seeking and Processing Model
Key_Findings: (1) risk information messages increase perception of information insufficiency and information seeking

Title: Predicting Intentions to Engage With Scientific Messages on Twitter: The Roles of Mirth and Need for Humor
Key_Findings: (1) humor mediates engagement intentions

Title: “Knowledge Is Power”: A Mixed-Methods Study Exploring Adult Audience Preferences for Engagement and Learning Formats Over 3 Years of a Health Science Festival
Key_Findings: (1) lectures work better than dialogue formats

Title: The Power of Being Transported: Efficacy Beliefs,Risk Perceptions,and Political Affiliation in the Context of Climate Change
Key_Findings:
(1) transportation affects efficacy beliefs and risk perception
(1) Political belief affects efficacy beliefs and rsk perceptions

Title: Learning From Science News via Interactive and Animated Data Visualizations: An Investigation Combining Eye Tracking,Online Survey,and Cued Retrospective Reporting
Key_Findings: (1) interactivity and animation engage audience more strongly -- translates into highr learning

Title: Science Information in Fictional Movies: Effects of Context and Gender
Key_Findings: (1) incorrect science is accepted as true from movies depend on gender of participant and the centrality of information in relation to the plot

Title: Putting Environmental Infographics Center Stage: The Role of Visuals at the Elaboration Likelihood Model’s Critical Point of Persuasion
Key_Findings: (1) visual content is important for persuasiveness of message

Title: Hedged Language and Partisan Media Influence Belief in Science Claims
Key_Findings:
(1) hedged language influence belief in information for individuals with certain epistemic profiles
(1) higher faith in instititutoin leads to lower belief in claims from scientific sources

Title: Third-Person Perception of Science Narratives: The Case of Climate Change Denial
Key_Findings:
(1) Individuals are aware of influence of narratives and can resist the influence when they perceive the message to have negative influence
(2) otherwise they underestimate influence of narratives

Title: Can a Personality Trait Predict Talk About Science?: Sensation Seeking as a Science Communication Targeting Variable
Key_Findings: (1) Sensation seeking predicts talk about science

Title: Science Exemplars in the Eye of the Beholder: How Exposure to Online Science Information Affects Attitudes
Key_Findings: (1) Exemplar reading fosterede longer reading amongst high empathy individuals but less exposure among high-nmumeracy individuals

Title: The Impact of Climate Change–Related Imagery and Text on Public Opinion and Behavior Change
Key_Findings:
(1) Perceived efficacy and issue importance correlate with  change in behavior
(2) exposure to images does not negatively affect perceived efficacy or perceived importance

Title: How Involvement,Citation Style,and Funding Source Affect the Credibility of University Scientists
Key_Findings: (1) funding source or citation style does not affect perceived credibility

Title: Environmental Science in the Media: Effects of Opposing Viewpoints on Risk and Uncertainty Perceptions
Key_Findings: (1) reading discredited opposiing viewpoint influence risk and uncertainty perception similarly as reading balanced opposiing viewpooints

Title: Emotion and judgments of scientific research
Method: scientific understanding questionnaire,judgment questionnaire,trust questionnaire,reasoning ability test
Key_Findings: (1) disgust increse negative judgment of research and scientists.

Title: Audience responses to television news coverage of medical advances: The mediating role of audience emotions and identification
Key_Findings: (1) news stories with human example intensify positive emotions

Title: Disgusting microbes: The effect of disgust on perceptions of risks related to modifying microbiomes
Key_Findings: (1) disgust increase risk perception

Title: Does a picture tell a thousand words? The uses of digitally produced,multimodal pictures for communicating information about Alzheimer’s disease
Key_Findings: (1) pictures are useful for evoking emotions,rather than convey spicific messages

Title: Fostering Climate Change consensus: The role of intimacy in group discussions
Key_Findings: (1) intimacy increases likelihood of reaching consensus and change of opinion

Title: Public perceptions of expert disagreement: Bias and incompetence or a complex and random world?
Key_Findings:
(1) people with low education and low self-knowledge attribute expert disbutes to incompetence
(2) people with high self-report knowledge attribute dispute to ideological or financial reasons
(3) high education attribute disputes to natural factors such as complexity

Title: Call them COVIDiots: Exploring the effects of aggressive communication style and psychological distance in the communication of COVID-19
Key_Findings: (1) agressive commuinication may generate positive outcome when dealing with public understanding

Title: Relationships among affective factors and preferred engagement in science-related activities
Key_Findings: (1) development of science competency may not be the best way to ensure public engagement and undderstanding of science

Title: A review of the effects of uncertainty in public science communication
Key_Findings: (1) most credibility-reduction effects of uncertainty are from consensus uncertainty

Title: Stop avoiding the inevitable: The effects of anthropomorphism in science writing for non-experts
Key_Findings: (1) Anthropomorphism is evocative without causing significant misconceptions

Title: Hot topics in science communication: Aggressive language decreases trustworthiness and credibility in scientific debates
Key_Findings:
(1) person introduced as a lobbyist decrease perceived trustworthiness
(2) Aggressive language is perceived as less trustworthy

Title: Shifting public engagement: How media coverage of Climate Change conferences affects Climate Change audience segments
Key_Findings: (1) media effects may be limited in changing public opinion due to dis(confirmation) effects

Title: Adolescent responses toward a new technology: first associations,information seeking and affective responses to ecogenomics
Key_Findings: (1) adolescent information seeking is mostly internet,books and science communication professionals were judged as most trustworthy information source

Title: Conflicting stories about public scientific controversies: Effects of news convergence and divergence on scientists’ credibility
Persuasive images in popular science: Testing judgments of scientific reasoning and credibility
Key_Findings: (1) images alone may not have strong effect on persuasiveness

Title: Abstract or concrete? The effect of Climate Change images on people’s estimation of egocentric psychological distance
Key_Findings: (1) abstract images increase perception of Climate Change as distant issue

Title: Framing effects on risk perception of nanotechnology
Key_Findings: (1) different types of benefit framing does not affect risk perception

Title: Naming is framing: The framing effect of technology name on public attitude toward automated vehicles
Key_Findings: (1) Technology naming influence behavioral intention through cognitive and affective responses

Title: Transformation of the media landscape: Infotainment versus expository narrations for communicating science in online videos
Key_Findings: (1) expository narration is liked and believed more than infotainment. However,viewers without university hbackground prefer infotainment.

Title: Knowledge,(mis-)conceptions,risk perception,and behavior change during pandemics: A scoping review of 149 studies
The spread of fake science: Lexical concreteness,proximity,misinformation sharing,and the moderating role of subjective knowledge
Key_Findings: (1) concrete misinformation prime psychological proximity which increases threat perception

Title: Religiosity as a perceptual filter: examining processes of opinion formation about nanotechnology
Key_Findings:
(1) risk and benefit perceptions drive public support for funding tech,not levels of knowledge
(2) rekuguiys belief indirectly affect levels of support

Title: The role of scientific knowledge in shaping public attitudes to GM technologies
Key_Findings: (1) knowledge increases likelihood of differentiated opinions

Title: Public participation processes related to nuclear research installations: What are the driving factors behind participation intention?
Key_Findings: (1) Moral norms and attitudes towards participation are strongest predictor of participation intention

Title: Investigating public science interest and understanding: evidence for the importance of free-choice learning
Key_Findings: (1) Science information comes from many different places,including leisure time and free-choice learning

Title: Scientists as comedians: The effects of humor on perceptions of scientists and scientific messages
Key_Findings: (1) respondents who perceive more humor had more positive views about comedy as source of scientific information

Title: Emotion and the Psychological Distance of Climate Change
Key_Findings:
(1) Reduced psychological distance leads to increase in emotions such as anger,fear,sadness,and guilt
(2) Increased psychological distance leads to increase in abstract emotion,such as hope
(3) anger,anxiety and hope had more impact on mitigation action and policy support than fear,guilt,and shame

Title: Using Political Efficacy Messages to Increase Climate Activism: The Mediating Role of Emotions
Key_Findings:
(1) Exposure to efficacy information influence hope and fear,but not anger
(2) effects vary by political idealogy
(3) exposure to efficacy information increases participation via hope

Title: Effects of Goal Framing and Emotions on Perceived Threat and Willingness to Sacrifice for Climate Change
Method: perceived threat questionnaire,willingness to sacrifice questionnaire
Key_Findings:
(1) Gain-negative frames increase perceived threat and willingness to sacrifice
(2) Loss frames increase perceived threat and willingness to sacrifice mediated by guilt and fear
(3) gain-positive frame increase perceived threat and willingness to sacrifice through hope

Title: A public health frame arouses hopeful emotions about Climate Change
Key_Findings:
(1) Public health focus ilicit most emotional reaction and support for CC mitigation
(2) National security frame may elicit anger

Title: Message framing influences perceived Climate Change competence,engagement,and behavioral intentions
Key_Findings: (1) Motivational framing works better than sacrifice framing to increase engagement

Journal_Book: Journal of Applied Research in Memory and Cognition
Title: When Fairness is Flawed: Effects of False Balance Reporting and Weight-of-Evidence Statements on Beliefs and Perceptions of Climate Change
Key_Findings:
(1) Contrarian claims make issues seem more contentious,reduce perceived competence
(2) statements about broader consensus can improve perception

Title: Understanding the relationship between sharing personal anecdotes,warmth,curiosity,risk perception and mitigation in communicating the threat of Climate Change
Key_Findings:
(1) Anecdotes don't affect curiosity or risk perception
(2) There is positive relationship between curiosity and risk perception and between trust in scientists and risk perception.

Title: Uniquely disgusting? Physiological disgust and attitudes toward GM food and other food and health technologies
Key_Findings: (1) Disgust drives skepticism towards GM food,but not other food and health technologies

Title: Co-benefits associated with public support for climate-friendly COVID-19 recovery policies and political activism
Method: co-benefit questionnaire,policy support questionnaire,intention to engage questionnaire
Key_Findings:
(1) perceptions of co-benefits of actions to address Climate Change and infectious disease is associated with policy support and engagement
(2) Effect mediated through perceived efficacy

Title: Toward a theory of persuasive hope: effects of cognitive appraisals,hope appeals,and hope in the context of Climate Change
Key_Findings: (1) hope appeals is persuasive and motivates behavior

Title: Taking Climate Change here and now – mitigating ideological polarization with psychological distance
Key_Findings: (1) Ideological polarization in CC perception is reduced when presented with closeness frames contra distant framing. However,cultural worldwiev and environmental value still had consistent influence regardless of framing

Title: Collective guilt mediates the effect of beliefs about global warming on willingness to engage in mitigation behavior
Key_Findings: (1) Collective guilt mediates willingness to engage in mitigating behaviour

Journal_Book: Journal of Personality and Social Psychology
Title: The Role of Transportation in the Persuasiveness of Public Narrative
Key_Findings: (1) Transportation (absorption into a story) leads to more story-consistent beliefs and evaluations

Title: Emotions Shape Decisions through Construal Level: The Case of Guilt and Shame
Stimulus: Verbal instructions to recall shameful/previous day events
Method: intention to participate questionnaire,observed choice of MP3
Key_Findings: (1) Guilt and shame affect differently

Title: The Future is Now: Reducing Psychological Distance to Increase Public Engagement with Climate Change
Method: psychological distance questionnaire,intention to mitigate questionnaire
Key_Findings: (1) Frames that reduce psychological distance are best for increasing public engagement

Title: “Fear Won't Do It”: Promoting Positive Engagement With Climate Change Through Visual and Iconic Representations
Key_Findings:
(1) Fear is ineffective for motivating personal engagement
(2) Nonthreatening images and icons that link to everyday emotions and concerns are most engaging.

Title: Does reduced psychological distance increase climate engagement? On the limits of localizing Climate Change
Key_Findings: (1) Reduced psychological distance does not translate into increased policy support

Title: The role of emotion in global warming policy support and opposition
Key_Findings:
(1) Discrete emotions are stronger predictor of policy support than cultural worldview,negative affect,image asociaations or sociodemographic variable
(2) worry,interest and hope are strongly associated with policy support.

Journal_Book: Environmental Communication A Journal of Nature and Culture
Title: Portraying the perils to polar bears: The role of empathic and objective perspective-taking toward animals in Climate Change communication
Key_Findings:
(1) No benefit from taking objective instead of empathetic framing
(2) Portrayals of polar bears harmed motivate to donate money to environmental activist groups. Empathy and hope explain effects for environmentalists,empathy,hope,worry,personal guilt and boredom explain effects for non-environmentalists

Title: Who is afraid of the Ebola outbreak? The influence of discrete emotions on risk perception
Method: risk perception questionnaire,emotion questionnaire,intention to mitigate questionnaire
Key_Findings:
(1) fear,anget,anxiety,disgust and sadness are positively related to risk perception
(2) Fear inhibit effect of risk information on pariticipants' support for mitigation measures

Title: Boomerang effects in science communication: How motivated reasoning and identity cues amplify opinion polarization about climate mitigation policies
Key_Findings:
(1) Political partisanship conditions identification with potential victims
(2) Partisanship increase degree of political polarization and resulted in boomerang effect

Title: Exploring the framing effects of emotion do discrete emotions differentially influence information accessibility,information seeking,and policy preference?
Key_Findings: (1) Fear and anger can differentially affect information accessibility,information seeking,and policy preference

Title: Dealing with feelings: Positive and negative discrete emotions as mediators of news framing effects
Key_Findings: (1) anger and enthusiasm mediate framing effects,contentment and fear do not

Title: The effects of emotional appeals and gain versus loss framing in communicating sea star wasting disease
Key_Findings:
(1) Sadness appeal is effective to promote information seeking and policty support hope is ineffective in this context
(2) sadness is more effective with gain framing hope have great impact with loss framing

Title: Exploring the role of incidental emotions in support for Climate Change policy
Key_Findings: (1) guilt increase support for policies

Title: Role of negative emotion in communication about CO2 risks
Key_Findings: (1) fear affect processing of information and resulted in favorable attitude toward energy conservation

Title: Framing and communicating Climate Change: The effects of distance and outcome frame manipulations
Key_Findings:
(1) gain frames increase perceived severity
(2) better effect of gain frame partially suppressed by lower fear response and poorer information recall

Title: Framing,partisan predispositions,and public opinion on Climate Change
Key_Findings:
(1) local framing increase perception of severity and support for policy
(2) benefit framing weakens perceptions of severity and support for policy action

Title: Negative emotion and message processing
Key_Findings: (1) fear leads to more careful information processing

Title: The effect of framing and normative messages in building support for climate policies
Key_Findings: (1) gain-frame effective for policy support

Title: Climate Change risk perception and policy preferences: the role of affect,imagery,and values
Method: risk perception questionnaire,policy support questionnaire,emotion questionnaire
Key_Findings: (1) risk perception and policy support is influenced by affect,imagery,and values

Title: Fish Tales: How Narrative Modality,Emotion,and Transportation Influence Support for Sustainable Aquaculture
Key_Findings:
(1) Text is more transporting than video
(2) transporting lead to lower risk perception and high support

Title: Stars—They’re Sick Like Us! The Effects of a Celebrity Exemplar on COVID-19-Related Risk Cognitions,Emotions,and Preventative Behavioral Intentions
Key_Findings: (1) Celebrity examples increase anxiety and increase engagement in preventive behavior

Title: Communicating Food Safety via the Social Media: The Role of Knowledge and Emotions on Risk Perception and Prevention
Key_Findings: (1) Emotional response is predictor of safety risk perception and preventive action compared to factual awareness

Title: Do PSAs Take a Bite Out of Shark Week? The Effects of Juxtaposing Environmental Messages With Violent Images of Shark Attacks
Key_Findings: (1) public service announcements increase fear and perceived threat and affect support for policy and information seeking.

Title: A Metacognitive Approach to Reconsidering Risk Perceptions and Uncertainty: Understand Information Seeking During COVID-19
Key_Findings:
(1) risk perception and uncertainty predict information seeking
(1) hope effect depend on interaction between uncertainty and risk perception

Title: Images That Engage People With Sustainable Urban Water Management
Key_Findings: (1) images of ocean ilicit positive emotions,stormwater evoked negative emotions,

Title: Scared Yet Compassionate? Exploring the Order Effects of Threat Versus Suffering Messages on Attitude Toward Scary Victims
Key_Findings: (1) compassion,not fear,mediate effects of threat and suffering messages

Title: A Social Identity Approach to Engaging Christians in the Issue of Climate Change
Key_Findings: (1) framing environmental protection as a moral and religious issue is effective

Title: The Effects of Establishing Intimacy and Consubstantiality on Group Discussions About Climate Change Solutions
Key_Findings: (1) intimate groups more likely to exhibit commonality

Title: Communicate hope to motivate the public during the COVID-19 pandemic
Key_Findings: (1) hope oriented visual communication motivates public action more than fear-oriented communication
